messageBody:
CALL FOR PAPERS:
JOURNAL OF THE ASSOCIATION FOR SOFTWARE TESTING

The Journal of the Association for Software Testing (
http://associationforsoftwaretesting.org/) is seeking papers on the
theory, practice, and teaching of software testing for its first
issues. We welcome papers from scholars and from practitioners in the
field. We will also consider proposals for special issues organized by
a guest editor.

We welcome submissions at any time, but our tentative deadline for
articles for the first issue is September 1, 2005.

The emphasis of the first issue will be on putting the field in
perspective. There are some very strongly different visions of testing.
A broad paper that gives the reader insight into one of those visions
(along with supporting empirical data or literature review) would be
particularly welcome. Well-researched and well-documented attacks on
other viewpoints are as welcome as well-researched and well-documented
advocations.

Submissions outside of this emphasis will still be considered, but
might be published in the next issue.

The Charter for the Journal is at the end of this message, as is a list
of members of our Editorial Board. The Charter describes in more detail
the types of papers that we will consider.

To submit a paper, please send the manuscript to Cem Kaner,
kaner@....

Authors are encouraged to submit abstracts before writing and sending
papers. The abstract can be any reasonable length. Abstracts will be
rapidly evaluated, not peer reviewed. The response to the abstract will
be brief, of the nature "Yes, this appears to be within the scope of
the Journal and could be a promising paper" or "No, we are not likely
to accept a paper along these lines." A positive response to an
abstract will not be a commitment to publish the associated paper, nor
is a negative response a guaranteed rejection of the associated paper.
It is merely a rough, informal indicator that might save some
prospective authors some time.

We expect to publish the Journal on the Web, under a Creative Commons
license that allows anyone to reprint the article but not to modify it.
Articles will be formatted consistently, paginated consecutively across
issues, within an annual volume. It will *look* like a traditional
printed journal, but it will be available to the testing community for
free. We follow the style of the American Psychological Association
(http://www.apastyle.org/) largely because this is the most carefully
defined and most accessible professional society style available to
prospective authors.

AST is a recently-formed nonprofit professional service organization
dedicated to advancing the understanding and practice of software
testing. The AST serves a community of scholars, students, and software
development practitioners by providing forums for discussion of all
aspects of software testing through conferences, publications, web
sites, and other services.

=============================================================
EDITORIAL CHARTER OF THE
JOURNAL OF THE ASSOCIATION FOR SOFTWARE TESTING

The primary purpose of the Journal of the Association for Software
Testing is to publish peer-reviewed materials of archival value that
advance the understanding and practice of software testing. The Journal
will accept a wide range of original, unpublished materials.

JAST is published electronically rather than in print. As a result,
printing costs do not constrain the length of articles. Articles can be
of any length, but must be concisely written; verbose articles will be
returned to the author for revision.

EMPIRICAL & THEORETICAL RESEARCH (Peer Reviewed)

JAST welcomes original scientific and engineering research reports.
Papers that focus on a mathematical model are welcome; however our
strong preference is that such a paper include data that at least
establishes the plausibility of the model.

Model journals for articles in this category

• ACM Transactions on Software Engineering and Methodology
• IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering
• Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory & Cognition
• Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
• Perception & Psychophysics

We encourage authors to include appendices that provide fine details of
experimental methods or a finer-grained presentation of the
experimental data.

LITERATURE REVIEWS (Peer Reviewed)

A literature review is a thorough guided tour through the published
material related to a specific question or topic. The author of the
review helps the reader make sense of the topic under discussion, its
literature, and the controversies in the literature. A review may be
written at the level of a tutorial (for people who are somewhat
knowledgeable about testing in general but not about this topic in
particular) or at a level that assumes a professional understanding of
the field. A tutorial-level paper should be appropriate as a
required-reading assignment in an undergraduate course on software
testing. A professional-level paper should be appropriate for use in a
graduate course on software testing.

Within this category, we will also consider reflections. A reflection
is a narrowly-scoped review that puts years of the author's work in
perspective. For example, the head of a research laboratory might
describe the evolution and progress of her research program, its
successes, surprises and problems. A consultant might describe the
evolution of his practice. A manager of a corporate test group that
consciously innovates might describe the evolution of the group's
practice. A reflection must connect the described work to the scholarly
and/or practitioners' publications that guided or reported the work,
and to additional publications that will place the work in context for
the reader.

Literature review authors are welcome to build a case for a theoretical
position or viewpoint in their review, but must provide references to
the strongest references that would disagree with them.

Reviews may cover any area of testing, including ethics, methodology,
education and training, law, or commercial issues (such as outsourcing
or certification). The editor and reviewers must be convinced however
that the topic or question is relevant, important, and is covered
thoroughly, fairly, and in a way that makes sense of the topic for the
reader.

Much of the interesting work in testing was first done in industry and
presented in industry conferences or as technical reports on private
websites. References to these are encouraged, especially when a copy of
the referenced report is still available to the general public.

Model journals for articles in this category:

• ACM Computing Surveys
• Psychological Bulletin
• John Marshall Journal of Computer and Information Law

CASE STUDIES (Peer Reviewed)

A case study provides an in-depth description of an actual application
or use of a model or theory, a tool, a technique, or a process. A good
case study is typically rich in details, especially details that help
us understand how and why the model (theory, tool, technique, process)
was (or was not) valuable and what we can do to make application
easier, cheaper, or more successful. The details trigger and support
insights and help readers form hypotheses, rather than providing
proofs. Case studies present editorial challenges. For example, we
prefer to know the real names of companies and products, but ethical or
legal considerations sometimes make this impossible. Another example:
we will err on the side of rejection if we suspect that a particular
report is a marketing document for a tool vendor or consultant. We
encourage authors to disclose their backgrounds, biases, and potential
conflicts of interest, but will not publish the sociopolitical rants
that sometimes make up case study disclosures. We expect case study
reports to be reflective. Nothing goes perfectly; few things
competently done fail completely. What could have been done differently
and why? What conclusions should we be less or more confident in
because of the details of the case? What hypotheses does the case
suggest for research, and what methodological suggestions does it
provide for executing the research?

A narrower type of case study is the failure analysis. A failure
analysis considers a failure that was caused by a defect in the design
or implementation of software. As with the longer case study, the
article should provide details—publicly-verifiable details if the
product is identifiable—and guidance to the reader as to the underlying
lessons to take away.

Ultimately, a key question for us will be whether the case study's
details will still be instructive for readers ten years from now.

ARTICLE SETS (Peer Reviewed)

An article set includes one or more original articles plus detailed,
reviewed comments and criticisms of each article. This can be a way for
authors who have competing views or approaches to square off in a
thorough, well-documented debate. We have seen some symposia,
especially legal symposia, that have created such an effect, but we're
willing to consider other structures.

We will not publish case studies that advocate the use of a particular
tool, but we might publish a set of case studies that allow the reader
to compare successes of competing tools. The critical question is
whether the set is likely to give a careful reader insights into the
class of tool (and the tool-associated techniques).

METHODOLOGICAL REPORTS (Peer Reviewed)

Methodological reports describe new equipment and methods for
conducting research. These are tutorials, from one scientist to
another, explaining how to conduct a specific type of experiment or how
to apply a specific type of equipment to a type of experiment. This is
not a place for vendor reports. Nor is it a place for re-explanations
of matters that already appear in textbooks. Models for such articles
can be found in:

• Behavior Research Methods, Instruments, & Computers

STATISTICAL METHODS & MODELS (Peer Reviewed)

JAST will occasionally accept tutorial articles on the use of
statistics or probability models in software testing. The burden of
persuasion is on the author to convince the editor that such an article
fills an important gap in the knowledge of readers of this journal.
Such a paper might establish context by citing examples of
misunderstanding of the computation, theory or use of the statistic or
probability model.

We have seen examples of such articles in:

• ASQ Technometrics
• Jurimetrics
• Psychological Bulletin

Authors are encouraged to submit a proposal for an article of this type
to the editor before submitting a manuscript. We suspect that
relatively few of these proposals will be accepted. For more author
guidance, see our Information For Authors.

POSITION PAPERS AND INTERVIEWS WITH FAMOUS PEOPLE (NOT Peer Reviewed)

The Journal will sometimes accept position papers, editorials, and
interviews of notable people in the field. The Editor may consult
colleagues in the evaluation of such a submission, but the final
decision is the Editor's alone. The Editor's primary question is
whether the article is likely to be of interest to readers of the
current issue and of continuing interest to future readers. For
example, an interview in which Richard Feynman explained how he
designed instructional materials might be of interest for decades.

REQUIREMENTS FOR PUBLICATION

Submitted materials must follow the style and guidelines of the
American Psychological Association. (See http://www.apastyle.org ) A
brief summary of the referencing style is available at
http://webster.commnet.edu/apa/apa_index.htm

Submitted articles must be written in English and be in final or
near-final form. Unless the editor has given prior permission to submit
a rough draft, rough drafts will be returned unreviewed.

Submitted materials must be original and unpublished. We will consider
articles that describe material originally presented at a conference,
but the article must substantially extend the conference presentation.
If a conference paper was published, this must be disclosed at time of
submission and the submitted article must be so differently worded from
the conference paper there is unquestionably no infringement of the
rights of the owner of copyright in the conference paper.

The person submitting an article must have the authority to publish it.
For example, we cannot accept and publish an article that reveals trade
secrets of the author's employer.

Finally, JAST has a zero-tolerance policy with regard to plagiarism.
JAST will not knowingly publish a plagiarized article and it will
reject without review, as a matter of policy, any submissions from
authors who previously submitted a plagiarized article to JAST.
